4. Lastly, a `setuid` binary that uses the ncurses library should be accessible to them.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This issue can only be exploited for privilege escalation by running a setuid application using ncurses locally on the victim system.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS score does not reflect the real-world impact of the issue, since the issue cannot be exploited by an external attacker.

extended_information.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

Make the `TERMINFO` environment variable and the default user-controlled terminfo database file un-writeable:

1. Identify the shell configuration file for the different user account in the system. The shell configuration file depends on the user's shell. Common examples include `.bashrc` for `Bash`, `.bash_profile` for `Bash login shells`, and `.profile` for `POSIX-compliant shells`. The file is typically located in the user's home directory.
2. Open the file with `root` access
3. Add the following line to make the TERMINFO environment variable un-writtable: 
```
export TERMINFO=
readonly TERMINFO
```
4. Still with `root` access, create an empty `.terminfo` file in the home directory of the user:
```
touch $HOME/.terminfo
```

vulnerabilities.summary: ncurses 6.3 before patch 20220416 has an out-of-bounds read and segmentation violation in convert_strings in tinfo/read_entry.c in the terminfo library.

extended_information.short_description: An out-of-bounds read in ncurses terminfo leads to memory leakage.
extended_information.full_description:
[ncurses](https://invisible-mirror.net/archives/ncurses/) (new curses) is a programming library providing an application programming interface (API) that allows the programmer to write text-based user interfaces (TUI) in a terminal-independent manner. It is a toolkit for developing "GUI-like" application software that runs under a terminal emulator.

The `convert_strings` function in the `terminfo` module of `ncurses` is vulnerable to an out-of-bounds read, leading to memory leakage. The bug is triggerable by means of the `/progs/tic` tool that ships with ncurses and compiles a terminfo source. An example of running the tic tool - 
```
/progs/tic -o /path/to/output/directory/ <TIC_SOURCE_FILEPATH>
```
The vulnerability can be triggered when the attacker controls the contents of the TIC_SOURCE file.

The [PoC](https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/bug-ncurses/2022-04/msg00014.html) published is a terminfo file with special characters and Unicode characters leading to a memory leakage and a crash when reading a bad address. It is hardly usable by an attacker as the leaked memory either causes a crash - and so the data leaked is not obtainable - or written to a local output file, which doesn't benefit remote attackers.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Either leads to a client program DoS or to a memory leak into a local file.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Remote exploitation is unlikely to happen or to be beneficial for the attacker.

The attacker should be able to control the contents of the terminfo source file, when the `tic` command is run -
`/progs/tic -o /path/to/output/directory/ <TIC_SOURCE_FILEPATH>`

In addition, the attacker must find a way to get the output file with the leaked memory information, which is very unlikely to happen.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A PoC has been published to reproduce the bug to leak memory contents.

vulnerabilities.summary: NCurse v6.4-20230418 was discovered to contain a segmentation fault via the component _nc_wrap_entry().

A vulnerability has been found in GNU ncurses up to 6.5-20250322 and classified as problematic. This vulnerability affects the function postprocess_termcap of the file tinfo/parse_entry.c. The manipulation leads to stack-based buffer overflow. The attack needs to be approached locally. Upgrading to version 6.5-20250329 is able to address this issue. It is recommended to upgrade the affected component.
A vulnerability was found in openldap. This security flaw causes a null pointer dereference in ber_memalloc_x() function.

libldap in certain third-party OpenLDAP packages has a certificate-validation flaw when the third-party package is asserting RFC6125 support. It considers CN even when there is a non-matching subjectAltName (SAN). This is fixed in, for example, openldap-2.4.46-10.el8 in Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

The nss_parse_ciphers function in libraries/libldap/tls_m.c in OpenLDAP does not properly parse OpenSSL-style multi-keyword mode cipher strings, which might cause a weaker than intended cipher to be used and allow remote attackers to have unspecified impact via unknown vectors.

slapd in OpenLDAP 2.4.45 and earlier creates a PID file after dropping privileges to a non-root account, which might allow local users to kill arbitrary processes by leveraging access to this non-root account for PID file modification before a root script executes a "kill `cat /pathname`" command, as demonstrated by openldap-initscript.

contrib/slapd-modules/nops/nops.c in OpenLDAP through 2.4.45, when both the nops module and the memberof overlay are enabled, attempts to free a buffer that was allocated on the stack, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (slapd crash) via a member MODDN operation.
An out-of-bounds read/write vulnerability was found in e2fsprogs 1.46.5. This issue leads to a segmentation fault and possibly arbitrary code execution via a specially crafted filesystem.

extended_information.short_description: An out-of-bounds write in e2fsck can lead to local privilege escalation when processing a crafted filesystem image.
extended_information.full_description:
[e2fsprogs](http://e2fsprogs.sourceforge.net/) is a set of utilities for maintaining the ext2, ext3 and ext4 file systems. Since those file systems are often the default for Linux distributions, it is commonly considered to be essential software.

A crafted malicious filesystem can cause a segmentation fault and arbitrary code execution in e2fsprogs. 

However, the attacker should either find an input that propagates and turns out to be passed to the `e2fsck` tool or use another vulnerability to upload the malicious filesystem image and find a way to pass it to `e2fsck`.

Its highly unlikely a remote service would use the `e2fsck` tool on externally supplied input.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attack must be performed locally, as its highly unlikely a remote service would use the `e2fsck` tool on externally supplied input.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The Denial-of-Service impact is mitigated since the only known attack vector is by running a forked process (`e2fsck`). Crashing a forked client process is usually not a severe impact. Also, the e2fsprogs tools are userland utilities, thus not affecting the kernel and cannot lead to a container escape.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must be able to put a crafted filesystem image on the target filesystem and have a privileged user execute the `e2fsck` tool on this image.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A Proof-of-Concept which leads to a Denial-of-Service was published by the reporting researcher.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Requires the user to run the `e2fsck` tool on a crafted filesystem.

vulnerabilities.summary:
**DISPUTED**A failure in the -fstack-protector feature in GCC-based toolchains 
that target AArch64 allows an attacker to exploit an existing buffer 
overflow in dynamically-sized local variables in your application 
without this being detected. This stack-protector failure only applies 
to C99-style dynamically-sized local variables or those created using 
alloca(). The stack-protector operates as intended for statically-sized 
local variables.

The default behavior when the stack-protector 
detects an overflow is to terminate your application, resulting in 
controlled loss of availability. An attacker who can exploit a buffer 
overflow without triggering the stack-protector might be able to change 
program flow control to cause an uncontrolled loss of availability or to
 go further and affect confidentiality or integrity. NOTE: The GCC project argues that this is a missed hardening bug and not a vulnerability by itself.

Libgcrypt before 1.8.8 and 1.9.x before 1.9.3 mishandles ElGamal encryption because it lacks exponent blinding to address a side-channel attack against mpi_powm, and the window size is not chosen appropriately. This, for example, affects use of ElGamal in OpenPGP.

extended_information.short_description: Timing data leak in libgcrypt ElGamal encryption can lead to key brute force when attackers can cause many decryption operations.
extended_information.full_description:
[Libgcrypt](https://gnupg.org/software/libgcrypt/index.html) is a general-purpose cryptographic library based on the code from GnuPG.
[ElGamal encryption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ElGamal_encryption) is a public-key cryptosystem that is widely used in OpenPGP for key management and encrypted communication.

In ElGamal encryption, the encryption operation involves raising a message to the power of the public key. An attacker might be able to perform a timing attack to extract information about the private key by observing the time it takes to perform the encryption.

To perform this attack, an attacker would need to be on the same machine or subnet where the decryption takes place, and be able to trigger many decryption operations (oracle attack).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker would need to be able to trigger many decryption operations (oracle attack).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: ElGamal is rarely used alone (used more as part of a hybrid encryption type)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Due to the nature of timing attacks, the attack would be much more successful by an attacker that can already run code on the machine that performs the decryption. At most, the attacker needs to be on the same subnet as the decryption machine.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The paper gives all the details to exploit this issue.

vulnerabilities.summary: cipher/elgamal.c in Libgcrypt through 1.8.2, when used to encrypt messages directly, improperly encodes plaintexts, which allows attackers to obtain sensitive information by reading ciphertext data (i.e., it does not have semantic security in face of a ciphertext-only attack). The Decisional Diffie-Hellman (DDH) assumption does not hold for Libgcrypt's ElGamal implementation.

A timing-based side-channel flaw was found in libgcrypt's RSA implementation. This issue may allow a remote attacker to initiate a Bleichenbacher-style attack, which can lead to the decryption of RSA ciphertexts.
Under some circumstances, this weakness allows a user who has access to run the ps utility on a machine, the ability to write almost unlimited amounts of unfiltered data into the process heap.
An issue was discovered in function _libssh2_packet_add in libssh2 1.10.0 allows attackers to access out of bounds memory.

extended_information.short_description: Out-of-bounds read in libssh2 `_libssh2_transport_read` may result in denial of service when using sftp, scp and channel functions.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of exploiting the DoS depends on the context of libssh usage. If libssh is used as an SSH client, the security impact of DoS is significantly lower than when using libssh as an SSH server.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The victim SSH server or client must call one of the following vulnerable functions -

* `libssh2_sftp_init`
* `libssh2_scp_send64`
* `libssh2_scp_send_ex`
* `libssh2_scp_recv`
* `libssh2_scp_recv2`
* `libssh2_channel_open_ex`
* `libssh2_session_handshake`

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Exploiting this vulnerability requires an attacker to manipulate `libssh` into a memory allocation that would result in an out-of-bounds read.
Currently there is no known proof-of-concept or technical explanation on how to achieve this.

vulnerabilities.summary: A vulnerability was found in systemd-resolved. This issue may allow systemd-resolved to accept records of DNSSEC-signed domains even when they have no signature, allowing man-in-the-middles (or the upstream DNS resolver) to manipulate records.
A vulnerability was found in systemd. This security flaw can cause a local information leak due to systemd-coredump not respecting the fs.suid_dumpable kernel setting.

An issue was discovered in systemd 253. An attacker can modify a sealed log file such that, in some views, not all existing and sealed log messages are displayed. NOTE: the vendor reportedly sent "a reply denying that any of the finding was a security vulnerability."

A vulnerability was found in systemd-coredump. This flaw allows an attacker to force a SUID process to crash and replace it with a non-SUID binary to access the original's privileged process coredump, allowing the attacker to read sensitive data, such as /etc/shadow content, loaded by the original process.

A SUID binary or process has a special type of permission, which allows the process to run with the file owner's permissions, regardless of the user executing the binary. This allows the process to access more restricted data than unprivileged users or processes would be able to. An attacker can leverage this flaw by forcing a SUID process to crash and force the Linux kernel to recycle the process PID before systemd-coredump can analyze the /proc/pid/auxv file. If the attacker wins the race condition, they gain access to the original's SUID process coredump file. They can read sensitive content loaded into memory by the original binary, affecting data confidentiality.

An issue was discovered in systemd 253. An attacker can modify the contents of past events in a sealed log file and then adjust the file such that checking the integrity shows no error, despite modifications. NOTE: the vendor reportedly sent "a reply denying that any of the finding was a security vulnerability."

Certain DNSSEC aspects of the DNS protocol (in RFC 4033, 4034, 4035, 6840, and related RFCs) allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (CPU consumption) via one or more DNSSEC responses, aka the "KeyTrap" issue. One of the concerns is that, when there is a zone with many DNSKEY and RRSIG records, the protocol specification implies that an algorithm must evaluate all combinations of DNSKEY and RRSIG records.

extended_information.short_description: Unbounded resource consumption in the DNSSEC extension of the DNS protocol may lead to denial of service when resolving a malicious domain.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker needs to make the victim resolver validate his malicious domain.
Note - This flaw is derived from the DNSSEC standard, thus every implementation of DNSSEC that follows the standard is vulnerable.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker needs to send a DNS query to the target resolver, requesting his malicious domain. The attack occurs when the resolver tries to validate the response from the DNS server.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A PoC was published, demonstrating denial of service.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Exploitation of the vulnerability causes high resource consumption, which leads to denial of service.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A technically detailed writeup of this vulnerability (under the name "keytrap") was published by the research team, ATHENE-RESEARC.

extended_information.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

Since the vulnerability affects many different DNS resolvers, remediation is on a case-by-case basis.

vulnerabilities.summary: An off-by-one Error issue was discovered in Systemd in format_timespan() function of time-util.c. An attacker could supply specific values for time and accuracy that leads to buffer overrun in format_timespan(), leading to a Denial of Service.

extended_information.short_description: An out-of-bounds write in systemd leads to denial of service when formatting timespans.
extended_information.full_description:
[systemd](https://systemd.io/) is a software suite that provides an array of system components for Linux-based operating systems. Its main aim is to unify service configuration and behavior across Linux distributions.

It was discovered that due to an off-by-one error in the `format_timespan` function in `time-util.c`, a 1-byte buffer overflow occurs, which may lead to a denial of service.

The issue requires control over both arguments of the vulnerable function: `t` and `accuracy`.

The vulnerable function is inside an internal header file, which isn't exported and is only used by the `systemd` utilities.
No user input is supplied to this function through the default `systemd` utilities.
Also, developing code and linking with the library `-lsystemd` doesn't give access to this function.
Therefore - on almost all systems there is no way to trigger this issue.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
On almost all systems there is no way to trigger this issue, since the vulnerable internal function cannot be called with external input -
1. The vulnerable internal function is not exported
2. All the `systemd` utilities that use this function, do not pass user data to the vulnerable arguments

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An internal test that overwrites one byte was published on the GitHub Issue.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The issue causes a 1-byte overflow, which is unlikely to cause a crash or any other impact in real-world environments.

vulnerabilities.summary: An issue was discovered in systemd 253. An attacker can truncate a sealed log file and then resume log sealing such that checking the integrity shows no error, despite modifications. NOTE: the vendor reportedly sent "a reply denying that any of the finding was a security vulnerability."
systemd, when updating file permissions, allows local users to change the permissions and SELinux security contexts for arbitrary files via a symlink attack on unspecified files.

extended_information.short_description: Improper update of SELinux labels in systemd allows root users to bypass SELinux via mount commands.
extended_information.full_description:
[`systemd`](https://systemd.io) is a Linux software suite that provides numerous tools and system components, mainly a system and service manager, who runs on system startup.
`systemd` before 239 improperly performs [`SELinux`](https://selinuxproject.org/) label updates when mounting drives, which makes it vulnerable to symlink attacks that may result in local privilege escalation. 

`SELinux` labels are used for access control, and help manage the access to resources based on user privilege. When `systemd` is required to mount user-specified drives or directories, it recursively updates the `SELinux` labels of the files inside the mounted directory tree, granting privileges to the mounting user to use those files. A vulnerability in `systemd`'s `label_fix` function allows an attacker to perform a symlink attack, in which a symlink to a sensitive resource exists in the mounted directory tree. This would result in the update of the `SELinux` label of the file pointed by the symlink, granting the mounting user privileges to use that resource, effectively bypassing SELinux.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The issue affects many distributions by default, when SELinux is enabled

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Bypass of SELinux by root users

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A local attacker must create symbolic links and perform mount commands

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker with high privileges
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Mounting requires root privileges

vulnerabilities.summary: An exploitable denial-of-service vulnerability exists in Systemd 245. A specially crafted DHCP FORCERENEW packet can cause a server running the DHCP client to be vulnerable to a DHCP ACK spoofing attack. An attacker can forge a pair of FORCERENEW and DCHP ACK packets to reconfigure the server.

extended_information.short_description: Improper packet source validation in systemd's DHCP client may lead to denial of service.
extended_information.full_description:
[`systemd`](https://systemd.io) is a Linux software suite that provides numerous tools and system components, mainly a system and service manager, that runs on system startup. The DHCP client in `systemd` 245 is vulnerable to a packet forging attack which may lead to denial of service.

`systemd`'s DHCP client is vulnerable to a forging attack, allowing an attacker to set the client to `RENEWING` state, by sending the target client a `DHCP FORCERENEW` packet. When `systemd`'s DHCP client starts, it broadcasts a transaction ID to the entire network, which can later be used to communicate with the client. Since `systemd`'s DHCP client doesn't validate the source from which the `DHCP FORCERENEW` packet came from, a malicious actor can set the client to `RENEWING` state, in which the DHCP client will await for its new IP, subnet and lease time assignment. The attacker can then send the target client a `DHCP ACK` packet that contains the desired IP address they wish to set for the target. Thus, an attacker can cause a denial of service by assigning the target with an IP address that will effectively prevent it from communicating with its network.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Exploitation can be easily performed by local network attackers, without needing to write complex exploit code

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by an unauthenticated attacker or an attacker with low privileges
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Attack can be performed by an unauthenticated attacker

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This vulnerability can be exploited over DHCP (local network attackers)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: systemd's DHCP client is vulnerable to the forging attack by default

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Temporary denial of service

vulnerabilities.summary: The Closest Encloser Proof aspect of the DNS protocol (in RFC 5155 when RFC 9276 guidance is skipped) allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (CPU consumption for SHA-1 computations) via DNSSEC responses in a random subdomain attack, aka the "NSEC3" issue. The RFC 5155 specification implies that an algorithm must perform thousands of iterations of a hash function in certain situations.

extended_information.short_description: Unbounded resource consumption in the DNSSEC extension of the DNS protocol may lead to denial of service in multiple DNS resolvers when resolving a malicious domain.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: DNS resolvers are vulnerable only when enabling DNSSEC validation, which is usually a non-default & rare configuration (excluding CDN providers).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Exploitation of the vulnerability leads to high resource consumption in the DNS resolver which may lead to denial of service.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker needs to query the vulnerable DNSSEC validator requesting it to resolve his malicious domain, leading to high resource consumption when validating the NSEC3 response from the attacker-controlled nameserver.

vulnerabilities.summary: A path traversal vulnerability exists in curl <8.0.0 SFTP implementation causes the tilde (~) character to be wrongly replaced when used as a prefix in the first path element, in addition to its intended use as the first element to indicate a path relative to the user's home directory. Attackers can exploit this flaw to bypass filtering or execute arbitrary code by crafting a path like /~2/foo while accessing a server with a specific user.

extended_information.short_description: Incorrect path limitation in curl's SFTP implementation can lead to path traversal when processing a path containing the `~` character.
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
curl's [SFTP implementation](https://everything.curl.dev/usingcurl/scpsftp) includes a special feature for URL paths, whereby using a tilde (`~`) in the first element of a path indicates that it should be relative to the user's home directory. As a result, the Curl_getworkingpath function in libcurl replaces `/~/` with the user's home path.

However, using `/~../` can bypass the path traversal logic in `Curl_getworkingpath` due to the tilde character. This resolves to `/home/user/../` and can allow attackers to access remote system path locations that were not intended to be accessible.

To fully exploit this issue and gain access to other users' home directories and retrieve files, attackers must compromise a highly privileged account.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker can only access files for which the compromised user account used to establish the SFTP transfer has been granted permission.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The path traversal possibilities from this issue are very limited.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This issue is very limited as the tilde character should be in the first path element and the user can only access files he has been given permission to access.

vulnerabilities.summary:
This flaw allows an attacker to insert cookies at will into a running program
using libcurl, if the specific series of conditions are met.

libcurl performs transfers. In its API, an application creates "easy handles"
that are the individual handles for single transfers.

libcurl provides a function call that duplicates en easy handle called
[curl_easy_duphandle](https://curl.se/libcurl/c/curl_easy_duphandle.html).

If a transfer has cookies enabled when the handle is duplicated, the
cookie-enable state is also cloned - but without cloning the actual
cookies. If the source handle did not read any cookies from a specific file on
disk, the cloned version of the handle would instead store the file name as
`none` (using the four ASCII letters, no quotes).

Subsequent use of the cloned handle that does not explicitly set a source to
load cookies from would then inadvertently load cookies from a file named
`none` - if such a file exists and is readable in the current directory of the
program using libcurl. And if using the correct file format of course.

extended_information.short_description: Unspecified low-severity vulnerability in libcurl (fix pending)
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
Daniel Stenberg, one of Curls core maintainers announced that a forthcoming release of Curl, version 8.4.0, is scheduled to be available one week from that date, on October 11th, 2023 at approximately 06:00 UTC. This release will fix two security vulnerabilities in curl.
One of these vulnerabilities is rated as having low severity - CVE-2023-38546.
As of the current moment, no specific details (such as affected versions) have been released.

While not much is known about CVE-2023-38545 the following has been verified by official sources -
1. CVE-2023-38545 is the worst security problem found in Curl in a long time. For reference, the last vulnerability that was given a High severity by the Curl project is CVE-2021-22901 that was reported in May 2011.
2. The vulnerability does not affect all users of Curl, the maintainers specifically mentioned there is still going to be a large chunk of users who will not be affected by these problems - probably due to attack preconditions of this vulnerability.
3. The vulnerability is rated High although the Curl project does theoretically support designating vulnerabilities as Critical (this never happened so far). This may be related to the previous point - not all users are affected.
4. There is no API nor ABI change in the coming curl release.

This advisory will be updated on October 11th 2023 as details emerge

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage due to the popularity of curl and its connection to CVE-2023-38545 (which has high severity)

vulnerabilities.summary: When doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously was used to issue a `PUT` request which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the subsequent `POST` request. The problem exists in the logic for a reused handle when it is changed from a PUT to a POST.

extended_information.short_description: API confusion in curl may leads to data leaks or other impact when using specific POST and PUT APIs.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The only vulnerable applications are applications that use the  `curl` library and call both CURLOPT_READFUNCTION and CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS on the same handle (see example in "Full Description").
The `curl` command-line utility is not vulnerable to this issue.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: No specific exploit code is required from the attacker

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The security impact of this issue in most cases would not be severe, and highly depends on the context of the calling code, since the bug causes unexpected data to be sent (the data from the READFUNCTION call will be sent, rather than the data from the POSTFIELDS call).

vulnerabilities.summary: An authentication bypass vulnerability exists in libcurl prior to v8.0.0 where it reuses a previously established SSH connection despite the fact that an SSH option was modified, which should have prevented reuse. libcurl maintains a pool of previously used connections to reuse them for subsequent transfers if the configurations match. However, two SSH settings were omitted from the configuration check, allowing them to match easily, potentially leading to the reuse of an inappropriate connection.

When libcurl is asked to perform automatic gzip decompression of
content-encoded HTTP responses with the `CURLOPT_ACCEPT_ENCODING` option,
**using zlib 1.2.0.3 or older**, an attacker-controlled integer overflow would
make libcurl perform a buffer overflow.

extended_information.short_description: Heap buffer overflow in Curl when compiled with very old versions of zlib may lead to remote code execution when connecting to malicious HTTP servers
extended_information.full_description:
[curl](https://curl.se/) is used in command lines or scripts to transfer data. 

When using with old versions of [zlib](https://zlib.net/) (a data-compression library), curl offers to manually parse gzip headers rather than passing it to zlib as is. It was found that the `gzip_do_write()` function is susceptible to a buffer overflow as a result of an integer overflow. This could lead to remote code execution since the heap buffer overflow is controlled both in size and content. 

Curl supports endlessly large gzip headers, which result in the repeated call for `gzip_do_write()`, incrementing the `z->avail_in` variable, keeping track of the size of the buffer required for the gzip header data. Because there is no limit to the size of the gzip header data, this may result in `z->avail_in` overflowing, leading to the allocation of a buffer much smaller than the data being stored, resulting in a buffer overflow.

The vulnerability is only exploitable when Curl is running with very old versions of zlib (1.2.0.3 or older, which is 21+ years old) and when the `CURLOPT_ACCEPT_ENCODING` option is set to `gzip` (non-default value).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
For the vulnerability to be exploitable, the user needs to have libcurl work with zlib version 1.2.0.3 or older, which is 21+ years old.

Furthermore, the user must set the `CURLOPT_ACCEPT_ENCODING` to `gzip`.

In addition, the user must connect to a malicious HTTP server using curl.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability has a technical write-up including a working PoC that demonstrates denial of service.

vulnerabilities.summary: An improper certificate validation vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way it supports matching of wildcard patterns when listed as "Subject Alternative Name" in TLS server certificates. curl can be built to use its own name matching function for TLS rather than one provided by a TLS library. This private wildcard matching function would match IDN (International Domain Name) hosts incorrectly and could as a result accept patterns that otherwise should mismatch. IDN hostnames are converted to puny code before used for certificate checks. Puny coded names always start with `xn--` and should not be allowed to pattern match, but the wildcard check in curl could still check for `x*`, which would match even though the IDN name most likely contained nothing even resembling an `x`.

extended_information.short_description: Improper certificate pattern matching in curl can lead to authentication bypass.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The official project maintainers assigned a "Low" severity to this vulnerability

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker could create a certificate with a partial wildcard in the International Domain Name (IDN) field

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Certificates issued by Certificate Authorities for the public Internet are not allowed to use "partial" wildcards, thus completely avoiding this issue.

In many circumstances, the control of host names used and the wildcards used in issued certificates are controlled by the same entity, making this unlikely to actually become a problem.

vulnerabilities.summary:
This flaw allows a malicious HTTP server to set "super cookies" in curl that
are then passed back to more origins than what is otherwise allowed or
possible. This allows a site to set cookies that then would get sent to
different and unrelated sites and domains.

It could do this by exploiting a mixed case flaw in curl's function that
verifies a given cookie domain against the Public Suffix List (PSL). For
example a cookie could be set with `domain=co.UK` when the URL used a lower
case hostname `curl.co.uk`, even though `co.uk` is listed as a PSL domain.

When curl is asked to use HSTS, the expiry time for a subdomain might
overwrite a parent domain's cache entry, making it end sooner or later than
otherwise intended.

This affects curl using applications that enable HSTS and use URLs with the
insecure `HTTP://` scheme and perform transfers with hosts like
`x.example.com` as well as `example.com` where the first host is a subdomain
of the second host.

(The HSTS cache either needs to have been populated manually or there needs to
have been previous HTTPS accesses done as the cache needs to have entries for
the domains involved to trigger this problem.)

When `x.example.com` responds with `Strict-Transport-Security:` headers, this
bug can make the subdomain's expiry timeout *bleed over* and get set for the
parent domain `example.com` in curl's HSTS cache.

The result of a triggered bug is that HTTP accesses to `example.com` get
converted to HTTPS for a different period of time than what was asked for by
the origin server. If `example.com` for example stops supporting HTTPS at its
expiry time, curl might then fail to access `http://example.com` until the
(wrongly set) timeout expires. This bug can also expire the parent's entry
*earlier*, thus making curl inadvertently switch back to insecure HTTP earlier
than otherwise intended.

When curl is instructed to download content using the metalink feature, thecontents is verified against a hash provided in the metalink XML file.The metalink XML file points out to the client how to get the same contentfrom a set of different URLs, potentially hosted by different servers and theclient can then download the file from one or several of them. In a serial orparallel manner.If one of the servers hosting the contents has been breached and the contentsof the specific file on that server is replaced with a modified payload, curlshould detect this when the hash of the file mismatches after a completeddownload. It should remove the contents and instead try getting the contentsfrom another URL. This is not done, and instead such a hash mismatch is onlymentioned in text and the potentially malicious content is kept in the file ondisk.

extended_information.short_description: A partial warning message in curl may lead to malicious file download and unspecified impact when using the metalink feature.
extended_information.full_description:
[Metalink](https://www.metalinker.org/) is an extensible metadata file format that describes one or more computer files available for download.

When using Metalink (`--metalink`), curl performs an additional check when the download ends to determine if the content hash matches the one provided in the Metalink XML file.

In case the content on the servers is replaced by another file and so causes a hash mismatch, curl will detect it, issues a warning but not fail the download.
The user may not notice the warning, and continue using the file as though it was fully trusted.

Usage of the Metalink feature is exceedingly rare, and as such [has been completely removed](https://daniel.haxx.se/blog/2021/06/07/bye-bye-metalink-in-curl/) in the latest curl version

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker simply needs to modify a downloaded file, either on the hosting server or on the traffic itself by utilizing a MitM attack

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Usage of the metalink curl flag (`--metalink`) is exceedingly rare

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The distinction between only showing a warning and failing the download completely, is not grave

extended_information.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

Disable Metalink support by compiling curl with `./configure --without-metalink`

vulnerabilities.summary: libcurl skips the certificate verification for a QUIC connection under certain conditions, when built to use wolfSSL. If told to use an unknown/bad cipher or curve, the error path accidentally skips the verification and returns OK, thus ignoring any certificate problems.

In curl before 7.86.0, the HSTS check could be bypassed to trick it into staying with HTTP. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS directly (instead of using an insecure cleartext HTTP step) even when HTTP is provided in the URL. This mechanism could be bypassed if the host name in the given URL uses IDN characters that get replaced with ASCII counterparts as part of the IDN conversion, e.g., using the character UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common ASCII full stop of U+002E (.). The earliest affected version is 7.77.0 2021-05-26.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in curl may lead to HSTS bypass when using IDN characters.
extended_information.full_description:
[curl](https://curl.se) is a command line tool and a library for transferring data, supporting various network protocols. 

[HTTP Strict Transport Security](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/HTTP_strict_transport_security) (HSTS) is a simple and widely supported standard to protect visitors by ensuring that their browsers always connect to a website over HTTPS. HSTS exists to remove the need for the common, insecure practice of redirecting users from `http://` to `https://` URLs.

[Internationalized Domain Names](https://help.dreamhost.com/hc/en-us/articles/215864977-Internationalized-domain-names-IDNs-) (IDNs) are domain names that contain characters other than unaccented Roman letters (A-Z), digits (0-9), and the hyphen. For instance, `.idn.icann.org` contains Japanese characters.

`curl` features an in-memory cache for `HSTS` hosts, so subsequent `HTTP-only` requests to a hostname present in the cache will get internally "redirected" to the `HTTPS` version.

It was discovered that the `HSTS` mechanism could be bypassed if the hostname in the given URL first uses `IDN` characters that get replaced with ASCII counterparts as part of the `IDN` conversion. Like using the UTF-8 character `U+3002` (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common `ASCII` full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the `HSTS` state and makes a clear text transfer. 

The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed with the non-default `--hsts` option.

Example command-line usage that can trigger this issue -
```
curl -v --hsts hsts.txt https://accounts.google.com
curl -v --hsts hsts.txt http://accounts.google.com
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
1. The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed with the `--hsts` option that caches the HSTS hosts and then subsequent HTTP requests with the `--hsts` option that checks if an HTTPS redirection should occur.
2. The exploitation of this vulnerability may only be useful in environments exposed to Man in the Middle attacks. This would give the attacker the ability to perform Man in the Middle on non-encrypted clear text communication, which is easier compared to encrypted communication when HTTPS is used.
3. The vulnerable application or server should execute `curl` that would access Internationalized Domain Names (IDNs), which is not common. Alternatively, the attacker should be able to control the requested URL that `curl` access and set it to an IDN address.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: HackerOne report has a detailed technical writeup that leads to HSTS bypass.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.summary: When curl is instructed to get content using the metalink feature, and a user name and password are used to download the metalink XML file, those same credentials are then subsequently passed on to each of the servers from which curl will download or try to download the contents from. Often contrary to the user's expectations and intentions and without telling the user it happened.

extended_information.short_description: Unexpected behavior in curl can lead to credential leakage when accessing a remote metalink XML with user credentials.
extended_information.full_description:
[Metalink](https://www.metalinker.org/) is an extensible metadata file format that describes one or more computer files available for download.

When curl accesses a Metalink XML with user credentials, the same credentials will be used to access each of the servers that are specified in the Metalink XML files, which is unexpected behavior. If one of these servers are accessed in a non-secure manner (ex. without TLS) or is attacker-controlled, credential leakage will occur.

An example of a vulnerable curl call -
`curl -u myuser:mypass --metalink https://www.somedomain.com/metalink.xml `

Usage of the Metalink feature is exceedingly rare, and as such [has been completely removed](https://daniel.haxx.se/blog/2021/06/07/bye-bye-metalink-in-curl/) in the latest curl version

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker simply needs to sniff network traffic in order to perform this attack

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Usage of the metalink curl flag (`--metalink`) is exceedingly rare, and one of the subsequent accesses would need to be attacker-sniffable. In addition to that, the metalink URL needs to be accessed with some set of credentials in order for the attack to have any impact

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The set of leaked credentials can lead to varying impacts, depending on which resources can be accessed with them

extended_information.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

Disable Metalink support by compiling curl with `./configure --without-metalink`

vulnerabilities.summary: When curl is told to use the Certificate Status Request TLS extension, often referred to as OCSP stapling, to verify that the server certificate is valid, it might fail to detect some OCSP problems and instead wrongly consider the response as fine.  If the returned status reports another error than 'revoked' (like for example 'unauthorized') it is not treated as a bad certficate.

libcurl's ASN1 parser code has the `GTime2str()` function, used for parsing an
ASN.1 Generalized Time field. If given an syntactically incorrect field, the
parser might end up using -1 for the length of the *time fraction*, leading to
a `strlen()` getting performed on a pointer to a heap buffer area that is not
(purposely) null terminated.

This flaw most likely leads to a crash, but can also lead to heap contents
getting returned to the application when
[CURLINFO_CERTINFO](https://curl.se/libcurl/c/CURLINFO_CERTINFO.html) is used.

When an application tells libcurl it wants to allow HTTP/2 server push, and the amount of received headers for the push surpasses the maximum allowed limit (1000), libcurl aborts the server push. When aborting, libcurl inadvertently does not free all the previously allocated headers and instead leaks the memory.  Further, this error condition fails silently and is therefore not easily detected by an application.

A cleartext transmission of sensitive information vulnerability exists in curl <v7.88.0 that could cause HSTS functionality fail when multiple URLs are requested serially. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of usingan insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. ThisHSTS mechanism would however surprisingly be ignored by subsequent transferswhen done on the same command line because the state would not be properlycarried on.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in curl may lead to HSTS bypass when using HSTS caching in-memory.
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
[HTTP Strict Transport Security](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/HTTP_strict_transport_security) (HSTS) is a simple and widely supported standard to protect visitors by ensuring that their browsers always connect to a website over HTTPS. HSTS exists to remove the need for the common, insecure practice of redirecting users from `http://` to `https://` URLs.

Curl supports `HSTS` local cache which can be used through the command line using the following syntax: `curl --hsts hsts.txt https://hsts.example.com`.
Curl also supports caching these `HSTS` headers in-memory instead of a file, by using the following syntax: `curl --hsts "" https://hsts.example.com`

It was discovered that when using the in-memory HSTS caching (`--hsts ""`) of curl, if more than one URL of the same domain is passed to the curl command line, and at least one of them (except the first one) starts with `http://` instead of `https://`, the request sent by curl will bypass the `HSTS` filter and use the insecure clear-text HTTP protocol.
This is despite the fact that the `--hsts` option should force the use of HTTPS.

For example, the following command line is insecure (take note of the use of in-memory HSTS caching and the same domain URLs): `curl --hsts "" https://hsts.example.com http://hsts.example.com`

Note: only the curl command line using the `--hsts` option is vulnerable. `libcurl` is not affected by this vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: HackerOne report has a detailed technical writeup that leads to HSTS bypass.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
1. The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed using the CLI with the `--hsts` option with an empty argument that caches the HSTS hosts in memory, and then subsequent HTTP requests to the same domain in the same command. (e.g. `curl --hsts "" https://hsts.example.com`)
2. The exploitation of this vulnerability may only be useful in environments exposed to Man in the Middle attacks. This would give the attacker the ability to perform Man in the Middle on non-encrypted clear text communication, which is easier compared to encrypted communication when HTTPS is used.
3. The vulnerable application or server should execute `curl` that would make multiple requests to the same domain in a single Curl command, which is not common. Alternatively, the attacker should be able to control the requested URL that `curl` access and set it.

vulnerabilities.summary: A vulnerability exists in curl <7.87.0 HSTS check that could be bypassed to trick it to keep using HTTP. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of using an insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. However, the HSTS mechanism could be bypassed if the host name in the given URL first uses IDN characters that get replaced to ASCII counterparts as part of the IDN conversion. Like using the character UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common ASCII full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the HSTS state and makes a clear text transfer. Because it would store the info IDN encoded but look for it IDN decoded.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in curl may lead to HSTS bypass when using IDN characters.
extended_information.full_description:
[curl](https://curl.se) is a command line tool and a library for transferring data, supporting various network protocols. 

[HTTP Strict Transport Security](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/HTTP_strict_transport_security) (HSTS) is a simple and widely supported standard to protect visitors by ensuring that their browsers always connect to a website over HTTPS. HSTS exists to remove the need for the common, insecure practice of redirecting users from `http://` to `https://` URLs.

[Internationalized Domain Names](https://help.dreamhost.com/hc/en-us/articles/215864977-Internationalized-domain-names-IDNs-) (IDNs) are domain names that contain characters other than unaccented Roman letters (A-Z), digits (0-9), and the hyphen. For instance, `.idn.icann.org` contains Japanese characters.

`curl` features an in-memory cache for `HSTS` hosts, so subsequent `HTTP-only` requests to a hostname present in the cache will get internally "redirected" to the `HTTPS` version.

It was discovered that the `HSTS` mechanism could be bypassed if the hostname in the given URL first uses `IDN` characters that get replaced with ASCII counterparts as part of the `IDN` conversion. Like using the UTF-8 character `U+3002` (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common `ASCII` full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the `HSTS` state and makes a clear text transfer. 

The cause of this issue is that `curl` would store the `HSTS` info `IDN`-encoded but look for it `IDN`-decoded, resulting from a partial fix for a similar issue: CVE-2022-43551.

The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed with the non-default `--hsts` option.

Example command-line usage that can trigger this issue -
```
curl -v --hsts hsts.txt https://accounts.google%E3%80%82com
curl -v --hsts hsts.txt http://accounts.google%E3%80%82com
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
1. The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed with the `--hsts` option that caches the HSTS hosts and then subsequent HTTP requests with the `--hsts` option that checks if an HTTPS redirection should occur.
2. The exploitation of this vulnerability may only be useful in environments exposed to Man in the Middle attacks. This would give the attacker the ability to perform Man in the Middle on non-encrypted clear text communication, which is easier compared to encrypted communication when HTTPS is used.
3. The vulnerable application or server should execute`curl` that would access Internationalized Domain Names (IDNs), which is not common. Alternatively, the attacker should be able to control the requested URL that `curl` access and set it to an IDN address.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: HackerOne report has a detailed technical writeup that leads to HSTS bypass.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.summary: An information disclosure vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 when doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously wasused to issue a `PUT` request which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.

extended_information.short_description: Handle reuse in libcurl may lead to context-dependent impact when sending a POST request after a PUT request.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
This flaw cannot be triggered with the command line tool, it requires using libcurl directly, and specifically calling the `curl_easy_setopt` API with the following flags one after another -
* `CURLOPT_READFUNCTION` - to set up a read callback that supplies data to the following PUT request
* `CURLOPT_PUT / CURLOPT_UPLOAD` - to perform a PUT request
* `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` - to (attempt to) supply data for the following POST request
* `CURLOPT_POST` - to perform a POST request (which will erroneously use the read callback previously set)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The official project maintainers assigned a "Low" severity to this vulnerability

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must find a remote input to the victim application that makes it send a PUT request and subsequently a POST request, using libcurl

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of the vulnerability depends on the data supplied in the `CURLOPT_READFUNCTION` callback and the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` data parameter. A possible impact is leakage of unintended data, since the callback is used for both the PUT and POST requests unintentionally (instead of just the PUT request)

vulnerabilities.summary: A vulnerability in input validation exists in curl <8.0 during communication using the TELNET protocol may allow an attacker to pass on maliciously crafted user name and "telnet options" during server negotiation. The lack of proper input scrubbing allows an attacker to send content or perform option negotiation without the application's intent. This vulnerability could be exploited if an application allows user input, thereby enabling attackers to execute arbitrary code on the system.

extended_information.short_description: Improper command sanitization in curl can lead to content passing through specific options when telnet is enabled.
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
An issue has been discovered in curl that allows an attacker to inject arbitrary Telnet commands via the Telnet option flag (`--telnet-option` in the command line or `CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS` in the code) when using three (rarely used) options - `TTYPE`, `XDISPLOC` and `NEW_ENV`.
 
The original report also mentions arbitrary code execution that finally turns out to be impossible. At most, it can only impact applications relying specifically on Telnet options but not the data sent to the server.

Example vulnerable invocation -
`curl --telnet-option NEW_ENV=a,b$(echo -ne "\xff\xf0INJECTED") telnet://server`
The above example will inject the "INJECTED" command

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Telnet is an inherently insecure protocol and an attacker is much more likely to be able to sniff or inject Telnet data using a Man-in-the-middle attack regardless of this vulnerability, which has very rare prerequisites

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker can inject arbitrary Telnet commands instead of the intended Telnet options

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Attackers must find an input that allows them to insert arbitrary values for the following Telnet options -
* `TTYPE`
* `XDISPLOC`
* `NEW_ENV`
Which is an extremely unlikely scenario

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: As described in the report, the impact and the very rare use of the affected Telnet options make the CVSS inconsistent.

vulnerabilities.summary: A denial of service vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way libcurl provides several different backends for resolving host names, selected at build time. If it is built to use the synchronous resolver, it allows name resolves to time-out slow operations using `alarm()` and `siglongjmp()`. When doing this, libcurl used a global buffer that was not mutex protected and a multi-threaded application might therefore crash or otherwise misbehave.

An authentication bypass vulnerability exists libcurl <8.0.0 in the connection reuse feature which can reuse previously established connections with incorrect user permissions due to a failure to check for changes in the CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION option. This vulnerability affects krb5/kerberos/negotiate/GSSAPI transfers and could potentially result in unauthorized access to sensitive information. The safest option is to not reuse connections if the CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION option has been changed.

extended_information.short_description: Connection reuse in curl may lead to authentication bypass when changing GSS delegation between requests.
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
GSS-API delegation is a mechanism where a server can obtain credentials from a client and use them to access resources on behalf of the client. This allows the server to act as a proxy for the client, using the client's credentials to access resources that the client may not have direct access to.

To delegate credentials, the client establishes a GSS-API security context with the server, and if the client supports delegation and has valid credentials, sends a "forwardable" ticket to the server. The server can then use this ticket to access resources on behalf of the client. 

libcurl can reuse a previously created connection even when the delegation option had been changed which could have made the effective user no longer have access, thus leading to doing the second transfer with the wrong permissions.

Specifically, connecting to the same server while changing the following setting - `CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION` (or `--delegation` in curl command line) will erroneously re-use a previously cached connection (if the previous connection has been made from the same process), which is unexpected.

GSS-API delegation can also be used with Kerberos. When using Kerberos with GSS-API delegation, the client obtains a Kerberos ticket-granting ticket (TGT) during authentication, which can be used by the server to obtain a service ticket for accessing resources on behalf of the client. The server can then use the service ticket to access resources on the client's behalf without requiring the client to re-authenticate.

It is highly unlikely that a user would suddenly no longer have access because of a change in delegation in the second request.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An exploit that demonstrates authentication bypass is available.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The maintainers referred to this issue as a security bug "mostly in theory".

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS does not take into account the high attack complexity & per-target research needed to exploit this issue.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The CVE is only exploitable when a single process uses libcurl or curl to perform multiple connections with an obscure flag that may change the effective delegation value - `CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION` or `--delegation` in curl's command line.

This flag is not commonly used and it's highly unlikely that two requests to the same server would have different delegations.
An attacker would usually not have control of the usage of these flags or their values.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: As with any authorization bypass, the impact of the issue depends on the actions performed by the re-used connection. Specifically, a re-used connection may still give access erroneously to attackers that lack valid credentials.

vulnerabilities.summary: An allocation of resources without limits or throttling vulnerability exists in curl <v7.88.0 based on the "chained" HTTP compression algorithms, meaning that a server response can be compressed multiple times and potentially with differentalgorithms. The number of acceptable "links" in this "decompression chain" wascapped, but the cap was implemented on a per-header basis allowing a maliciousserver to insert a virtually unlimited number of compression steps simply byusing many headers. The use of such a decompression chain could result in a "malloc bomb", making curl end up spending enormous amounts of allocated heap memory, or trying to and returning out of memory errors.

This flaw makes curl overflow a heap based buffer in the SOCKS5 proxy
handshake.

When curl is asked to pass along the host name to the SOCKS5 proxy to allow
that to resolve the address instead of it getting done by curl itself, the
maximum length that host name can be is 255 bytes.

If the host name is detected to be longer, curl switches to local name
resolving and instead passes on the resolved address only. Due to this bug,
the local variable that means "let the host resolve the name" could get the
wrong value during a slow SOCKS5 handshake, and contrary to the intention,
copy the too long host name to the target buffer instead of copying just the
resolved address there.

The target buffer being a heap based buffer, and the host name coming from the
URL that curl has been told to operate with.

extended_information.short_description: Heap overflow in curl and libcurl leads to remote code execution when connecting to malicious HTTP servers over SOCKS5 proxies with remote hostname resolving.
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
It was discovered that when connecting to a malicious HTTP server over a SOCKS5 proxy with remote hostname resolving (scheme `socks5h://`) a heap overflow can be triggered due to a long (attacker-controlled) hostname being copied to a small local heap-based buffer.

The vulnerability affects both the `curl` CLI tool and the `libcurl` library, but not under default conditions.

The `libcurl` library is only vulnerable if used in any of the following ways - 

* `CURLOPT_PROXYTYPE` set to type `CURLPROXY_SOCKS5_HOSTNAME`, ex. -
`curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_PROXYTYPE, CURLPROXY_SOCKS5_HOSTNAME)`

* `CURLOPT_PROXY` or `CURLOPT_PRE_PROXY` set to use the scheme `socks5h://`, ex. -
`curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_PROXY, "socks5h://...")`

* One of the proxy environment variables is set to use the `socks5h://` scheme. For example the environment variables `http_proxy`, `HTTPS_PROXY` or `ALL_PROXY`.


The `curl` CLI tool is only vulnerable if any of the following conditions are true -

* Executed with `--socks5-hostname` flag
* Executed with `--proxy` (`-x`) or `--preproxy` set to use the scheme `socks5h://`
* Executed with relevant environment variables as described above

Example of a vulnerable `curl` invocation -
`curl -x socks5h://myproxy.com malicioushost.com`

In addition to the following conditions, the `curl` CLI tool in version 8.x  is only vulnerable if the flag `--limit-rate` is set with a number smaller than 65541.
(To clarify, this additional condition is not required for exploitation of `libcurl` or `curl` CLI version 7.x)

[An exploit](https://gist.github.com/xen0bit/0dccb11605abbeb6021963e2b1a811d3) for this vulnerability is publicly available, which demonstrates denial of service via [read-access to an attacker-controlled pointer](https://twitter.com/_JohnHammond/status/1711976730775470564/photo/1). While remote code execution exploit has not been published or discussed at this time, heap overflows can often be exploited for remote code execution.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage due to the popularity of curl and the scarcity of high-severity vulnerabilities in curl.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: [An exploit](https://gist.github.com/xen0bit/0dccb11605abbeb6021963e2b1a811d3) for this vulnerability is publicly available, which demonstrates denial of service via [read-access to an attacker-controlled pointer](https://twitter.com/_JohnHammond/status/1711976730775470564/photo/1). While remote code execution exploit has not been published or discussed at this time, heap overflows can often be exploited for remote code execution.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Curl or libcurl must be configured to connect to an attacker-controlled HTTP server over a SOCKS5 proxy, with remote hostname resolving specifically enabled in the curl client.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Possible remote code execution

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Use of curl with SOCKS5 proxies with remote hostname resolving (`socks5h://` scheme) is rare.
In addition, the curl CLI tool in version 8.x is only vulnerable if the flag `--limit-rate` is explicitly set with a number smaller than 65541.

extended_information.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

Force curl to use local hostname resolving instead of remote hostname resolving when connecting to a SOCKS5 proxy

For example, replace `socks5h` -
`curl -x socks5h://someproxy.com`

With `socks5` -
`curl -x socks5://someproxy.com`

vulnerabilities.summary: A cleartext transmission of sensitive information vulnerability exists in curl <v7.88.0 that could cause HSTS functionality to behave incorrectly when multiple URLs are requested in parallel. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of using an insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. This HSTS mechanism would however surprisingly fail when multiple transfers are done in parallel as the HSTS cache file gets overwritten by the most recentlycompleted transfer. A later HTTP-only transfer to the earlier host name would then *not* get upgraded properly to HSTS.

When saving HSTS data to an excessively long file name, curl could end up
removing all contents, making subsequent requests using that file unaware of
the HSTS status they should otherwise use.

A use after free vulnerability exists in curl <7.87.0. Curl can be asked to *tunnel* virtually all protocols it supports through an HTTP proxy. HTTP proxies can (and often do) deny such tunnel operations. When getting denied to tunnel the specific protocols SMB or TELNET, curl would use a heap-allocated struct after it had been freed, in its transfer shutdown code path.

extended_information.short_description: Use-after-free in curl causes client crash when using the SMB or TELNET protocols through an HTTP proxy.
extended_information.full_description:
[curl](https://curl.se/) is a popular command line tool and library for transferring data with URLs.

`curl` can use an `HTTP proxy` to tunnel `TELNET` or `SMB` packets.
