However, if the `HTTP proxy` denies the tunneling operation, a vulnerability can occur that causes a use-after-free or double-free issue in the curl client. This issue occurs in the transfer shutdown code path, which means that an attacker cannot use it to write controlled data. Nevertheless, the issue can still cause crashes.

Example of command causing the curl client to crash:
`curl 0 -x0:80 telnet:/[j-u][j-u]//0 -m 01` (note: `telnet` can be replaced by `smb` and cause the same issue).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The command causing the crash was published: `curl 0 -x0:80 telnet:/[j-u][j-u]//0 -m 01` that is using an HTTP proxy (`-x`) and the telnet protocol (`telnet` keyword).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Crashing a forked process (the curl client) will usually not cause any security impact

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS score is not reflecting the unlikely condition for exploitation and the impact.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: As most HTTP proxies deny protocol tunneling, very rare applications will use both curl with the SMB/Telnet protocol and an HTTP proxy

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)

vulnerabilities.summary: An authentication bypass vulnerability exists in libcurl <8.0.0 in the FTP connection reuse feature that can result in wrong credentials being used during subsequent transfers. Previously created connections are kept in a connection pool for reuse if they match the current setup. However, certain FTP settings such as CURLOPT_FTP_ACCOUNT, CURLOPT_FTP_ALTERNATIVE_TO_USER, CURLOPT_FTP_SSL_CCC, and CURLOPT_USE_SSL were not included in the configuration match checks, causing them to match too easily. This could lead to libcurl using the wrong credentials when performing a transfer, potentially allowing unauthorized access to sensitive information.

extended_information.short_description: FTP connection reuse in curl may lead to authentication bypass when using specific FTP options.
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
libcurl can reuse a previously created FTP connection even when one or more options had been changed that could have made the effective FTP user a different one, thus leading to doing the second transfer with the wrong credentials.

Specifically, connecting to the same FTP server while changing one of the following options -

* `CURLOPT_FTP_ACCOUNT`
* `CURLOPT_FTP_ALTERNATIVE_TO_USER`
* `CURLOPT_FTP_SSL_CCC`
* `CURLOPT_USE_SSL`

will erroneously re-use a previously cached FTP connection (if the previous connection has been made from the same process), which is unexpected.
Note that while these options may affect the effective FTP user, these options are not usually used to specify the desired FTP user. The desired FTP user and password are set by the following options, which are not vulnerable to this issue (using different values for these options will invalidate cached connections) -
* CURLOPT_USERNAME
* CURLOPT_PASSWORD
* CURLOPT_USERPWD

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The maintainers referred to this issue as "probably never hurt a single user and is a rather contrived use case to trigger it"

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The CVE is only exploitable when a single process uses libcurl to perform multiple FTP connections with obscure flags that may change the effective FTP user - 
* `CURLOPT_FTP_ACCOUNT`
* `CURLOPT_FTP_ALTERNATIVE_TO_USER`
* `CURLOPT_FTP_SSL_CCC`
* `CURLOPT_USE_SSL`

These flags are not the common flags used for FTP authentication.
An attacker would usually not have control of the usage of these flags or their values.

The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: As with any authorization bypass, the impact of the issue depends on the actions performed by the re-used FTP connection. Specifically, a re-used connection may still give access erroneously to attackers that lack valid credentials

vulnerabilities.summary: In GNU Coreutils through 8.29, chown-core.c in chown and chgrp does not prevent replacement of a plain file with a symlink during use of the POSIX "-R -L" options, which allows local users to modify the ownership of arbitrary files by leveraging a race condition.

A flaw was found in GNU Coreutils. The sort utility's begfield() function is vulnerable to a heap buffer under-read. The program may access memory outside the allocated buffer if a user runs a crafted command using the traditional key format. A malicious input could lead to a crash or leak sensitive data.
chroot in GNU coreutils, when used with --userspec, allows local users to escape to the parent session via a crafted TIOCSTI ioctl call, which pushes characters to the terminal's input buffer.

nghttp2 is an implementation of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol version 2 in C. The nghttp2 library prior to version 1.61.0 keeps reading the unbounded number of HTTP/2 CONTINUATION frames even after a stream is reset to keep HPACK context in sync.  This causes excessive CPU usage to decode HPACK stream. nghttp2 v1.61.0 mitigates this vulnerability by limiting the number of CONTINUATION frames it accepts per stream. There is no workaround for this vulnerability.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in the implementation of the HTTP/2 protocol in Nghttp2 may lead to denial of service by abusing frame flags.
extended_information.full_description:
[Nghttp2](https://github.com/nghttp2/nghttp2) is an open-source implementation of HTTP/2, a significant upgrade to the HTTP protocol, offering improved efficiency and performance for web communication. It provides libraries and command-line tools for developers to integrate HTTP/2 features into their applications, including binary framing, header compression, multiplexing of requests, and server push. `Nghttp2` is widely used in various projects, such as web servers, proxies, and clients.

`HTTP/2` is a binary protocol where the client and server exchange binary frames instead of text lines as in `HTTP/1.x`. `HTTP/2` resolves numerous concerns found in HTTP/1.1 by organizing each HTTP message into a series of HTTP/2 frames. These frames include frame type, length, flags, stream identifier (ID), and payload.

The `HEADERS` frame type allows sending HTTP headers of, both, request and response. The `HEADERS` frame contains many flags.
The `CONTINUATION` frame type is similar to the `HEADER` frame, but it has just one flag: `END_HEADERS`. When it is not set, the peer knows that more headers are coming in the following `CONTINUATION` frames.

This mechanism allows an attacker to send an `HTTP/2` stream with `CONTINUATION` frames, without setting the `END_HEADERS` flag in any of the frames. This can cause denial-of-service when sending an excessive number of these crafted frames due to caching all frames in memory.

The issue is exploitable by default due to `Nghttp2` being an `HTTP/2`-only implementation.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Nghttp2 is vulnerable in its default configuration.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A very detailed technical write-up has been published regarding the issue.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This issue can lead to denial of service.

The issue has multiple mentions in general media
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This issue is related to the well-covered attack "HTTP/2 CONTINUATION Flood".

vulnerabilities.summary: The HTTP/2 protocol allows a denial of service (server resource consumption) because request cancellation can reset many streams quickly, as exploited in the wild in August through October 2023.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in the implementation of the HTTP/2 protocol may lead to DoS and ease the possibility of DDoS in web server applications by abusing request cancellation.
extended_information.full_description:
[The HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP) is a fundamental protocol of the World Wide Web, enabling the exchange of data between a client (typically a web browser) and a server. It defines the rules for requesting and transmitting web pages and other resources over the internet. Request and response messages are exchanged as a stream of ASCII characters, sent over a reliable transport layer like TCP.

[HTTP/2](https://http2.github.io/) is a modern network protocol designed to improve the performance and efficiency of web communication. It replaces the older HTTP/1.1 protocol and introduces features like header compression and enhanced request cancellation mechanisms, which collectively enhance the speed and responsiveness of websites.

This request cancellation mechanism allows clients to terminate unnecessary or redundant requests without waiting for a server's response, reducing network congestion and further improving the overall responsiveness of web applications.

HTTP/2 resolves numerous concerns found in HTTP/1.1 by organizing each HTTP message into a series of HTTP/2 frames. These frames include type, length, flags, stream identifier (ID), and payload. The stream ID is essential in clearly associating specific bytes on the network with their corresponding messages, facilitating secure multiplexing and concurrent processing. These streams are bidirectional, enabling clients to transmit frames, and servers to respond with frames using the same ID.

As detailed in [this technical analysis](https://blog.cloudflare.com/technical-breakdown-http2-rapid-reset-ddos-attack/), there's a vulnerability in the way request cancellation is implemented. The flaw lies in the process of sending an excessive number of requests (specifically, `HEADERS` frames), each immediately followed by a request cancellation frame utilizing the `RST_STREAM` frame. This sequence rapidly leads to a substantial consumption of server-side resources. Consequently, this vulnerability amplifies the risk of Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, making it easier to overwhelm and exhaust the server's available resources.

A lot of server applications are vulnerable to the Http/2 Rapid Reset attack.
However, note that HTTP/2 must be enabled, which is not the default configuration on most applications (excluding nghttp2 for example).
A non-exhaustive list of these vulnerable web applications:
```
- Tomcat
- Jetty
- NGINX on certain conditions
- nghttp2
- Netty
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A [PoC exists](https://github.com/imabee101/CVE-2023-44487) for this issue

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has been reported to be actively exploited in public networks
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Cloudflare identified this vulnerability being exploited in a DDoS attack of unprecedented scale on August 25, 2023, which surpassed their previous largest recorded attack by almost threefold.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker should attack a web server application with HTTP/2 protocol enabled and no (or a high) keepalive-requests options.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This issue can lead to DoS on popular server applications using HTTP/2 protocol and ease the possibility of DDoS attack.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage from Google, Cloudflare, and more.

vulnerabilities.summary: A vulnerability was found in zstd v1.4.10, where an attacker can supply empty string as an argument to the command line tool to cause buffer overrun.

extended_information.short_description: Out-of-bounds read in zstd may lead denial of service when using crafted command-line arguments.
extended_information.full_description:
[Zstandard](https://facebook.github.io/zstd/) is a fast lossless compression algorithm, providing high compression ratios and targeting real-time compression scenarios at zlib-level.
`zstd` is the reference implementation in C that offers a very wide range of speed / compression trade-off, and is backed by an extremely fast decoder.
It was discovered that running the `zstd` tool with arbitrary arguments can lead to an OOB read due to a design flaw, which may lead to a crash of `zstd`. Since `zstd` is a standalone (forked) tool - the crash has a minimal security impact.

Specifically, passing the `--output-dir-flat` or `--output-dir-mirror` arguments with an empty string, leads to an OOB read.

It should be noted that the OOB read is of 1 byte only, which on modern systems does not even lead to a crash (in most cases of production-built software)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Passing an empty string to the flags "--output-dir-flat" or "--output-dir-mirror" will trigger the 1-byte OOB read

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS does not take into account the high attack complexity and low real-world severity of this issue

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Crashing a forked process has minimal to no security impact. Furthermore, a 1-byte OOB read will not lead to a crash in almost all cases.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must be able to supply command line arguments to an invocation of the `zstd` CLI tool.

vulnerabilities.summary:
It was discovered that dpkg-deb does not properly sanitize directory permissions when extracting a control member into a temporary directory, which is
documented as being a safe operation even on untrusted data. This may result in leaving temporary files behind on cleanup. Given automated and repeated execution of dpkg-deb commands on
adversarial .deb packages or with well compressible files, placed
inside a directory with permissions not allowing removal by a non-root
user, this can end up in a DoS scenario due to causing disk quota
exhaustion or disk full conditions.
